item.title: Bespoke Supports Planning Materials
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Bespoke Supports Planning Materials are for social workers, link workers, CPNs and any other practitioners supporting people with younger onset dementia to plan.
What does it do? 

The Bespoke Supports Planning Materials contain two characters with younger onset dementia, Gordon and Lucy Ann. They contain tools to support the identification of outcomes for each character and a sample annual budget for each.

How can you use it? 
The Bespoke Supports Planning Materials could be used to promote and support learning in practitioner teams or individually.
item.dc:creator: Josie Vallely

item.title: Carer Support Planning Toolkit
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Carer Support Planning Toolkit is for carers and anyone supporting them to develop their support plans. When the Carers Support (Scotland) Act 2016 comes into force, all carers will be entitled to have a support plan.
What does it do? 

The Carer Support Planning Toolkit contains a set of conversation and planning tools to help carers and their supporters prepare to complete their support  plan.  Using the toolkit will ensure that the carer has had time to reflect on what would be best for them.

How can you use it? 
It is not necessary to use every tool in the Carer Support Planning Toolkit. Carers should pick the ones they find more relevant. It is suggested that the toolkit is worked through over more than one session to give time for reflection.
item.dc:creator: Josie Vallely

item.title: Community Connecting ABCD
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Community Connecting ABCD is for all health and social care workers and their employers.
What does it do? 

The Community Connecting ABCD provides simple principles and advice for practitioners who are looking to develop skills as  community connectors and their employers. . It supports good conversations and creative planning with people to achieve the outcome of building a person’s connections and relationships within their local community.

How can you use it? 
The Community Connecting ABCD could be given to practitioners and employers who are looking to develop strengths based approaches to self-directed support conversations and planning. It could also be used in team training and inductions.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dowling

item.title: Community Asset Map
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Community Asset Map is for anyone living and / or working in East Renfrewshire who wants to find out about and access community assets and resources. A community asset or resource is anything that improves the quality of community life.
What does it do? 

The Community Asset Map depicts community assets and resources on a map. These are colour coded for easy identification. The map can be displayed in public spaces and added to by community members.

How can you use it? 
The Community Asset Map can be used to map and share knowledge and information about community resources. It can be used by health and social care practitioners to facilitate self-directed support conversations and planning. It could also be used in team training and inductions. By providing information about the strengths and resources of a community it can help to uncover solutions.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dowling

item.title: Inkwell portraits - older people as assets
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The portraits are for anyone who wishes to celebrate older people in their local community. The three portraits displayed here are of the older people in the Ageing Well co-design team. They were gifted to them as a thank you from the co-design team for their contribution to the project.
What does it do? 

In the words of the artist, Andy Archer, the portraits ‘remind all generations that older people are treasure troves of adventure and knowledge’.

How can you use it? 
The portraits can be used to remind people that older people are assets to their communities. They can support good conversations to underpin strengths-based approaches to assessment and support planning.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dowling

item.title: Test Budgets
item.description:
Who is it for? 
Test budgets are for people planning their support and their supporters.
What does it do? 

The personalised ‘Taking the First Steps’ account is for people to record what they have spent their test budget on and what their outcomes have been.

How can you use it? 
Test budgets can be used to give people the opportunity to try out different activities and supports before including them in their support plans. They can also give people the opportunity to try managing small sums of money before deciding on which SDS option to choose.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dowling

item.title: SDS add-on to Support Plan
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The SDS add-on to Support Plan is for people with mental health problems and their supporters.
What does it do? 

The SDS add-on to Support Plan helps people with mental health problems to plan in advance for how they will manage their SDS when their condition fluctuates and they become unwell.

How can you use it? 
The SDS add–on to Support Plan can be used as an extension to assessment and support planning (WRAP is an option) to plan and record an SDS advance directive.
item.dc:creator: admin_pilotlight

item.title: Test Budgets for Substance Misuse Recovery
item.description:
Who is it for? 
Test budgets are for people in recovery from substance misuse
What does it do? 

The test budgets for recovery tool helps the person in recovery decide which of the recovery outcomes they want to focus on and to think through how they might use their budget to do this. It records progress made in spending the budget. It contains an invoice designed to ensure that the payment of the test budget will not impact on benefits.

How can you use it? 
Test budgets can be used to give people the opportunity to try out different recovery activities and supports before including them in their support plans. They can give people the opportunity to try managing small sums of money before deciding on which SDS option to choose. Test budgets can be useful myth busting tools, demonstrating that people do make good decisions about what to spend their budgets on.
item.dc:creator: Josie Vallely

item.title: Count Me In video
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Count Me In video is for anyone who want to know how SDS can be used to set up small businesses.
What does it do? 

The Count Me In video tells the story of how people in Moray are using SDS to set up small businesses.

How can you use it? 
The Count Me In video is for SDS commissioners and micro-enterprise development officers to use to promote the use of SDS for small business.
item.dc:creator: admin_pilotlight

item.title: Count Me In campaign
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Count Me In campaign is for providers, social workers, people with SDS budgets and business volunteers.
What does it do? 

The Count Me In campaign is a series of posters aimed at different stakeholders with the key message that SDS can be used for self employment.

How can you use it? 
The Count Me In campaign is for SDS commissioners and micro-enterprise development officers to use to promote the use of SDS for small business.
